name: Critical Connections in a Network
title: Critical Connections in a Network
content:
There are n servers numbered from 0 to n - 1 connected by undirected server-to-server connections forming a network where connections[i] = [ai, bi] represents a connection between servers ai and bi. Any server can reach other servers directly or indirectly through the network.

A critical connection is a connection that, if removed, will make some servers unable to reach some other server.

Return all critical connections in the network in any order.

 

Example 1:

Input: n = 4, connections = [[0,1],[1,2],[2,0],[1,3]]
Output: [[1,3]]
Explanation: [[3,1]] is also accepted.

Example 2:

Input: n = 2, connections = [[0,1]]
Output: [[0,1]]

 

Constraints:

  • 2 <= n <= 105
  • n - 1 <= connections.length <= 105
  • 0 <= ai, bi <= n - 1
  • ai != bi
  • There are no repeated connections.

discussion_posts.name: zhukuan042
discussion_posts.content:
Many solutions below mention about topological sorting which assumes that a "critical node" can not appear in any loop.
Image this example:
### [**[0,1],[0,2],[1,2]**,*[3,4],[3,5],[4,5]*,[1,3]]
in this case, node#0,1,2 forms a loop and node#3,4,5 froms another loop and bridge [1,3] connects these two loops. According to this problem description, I would say [1,3] is a "critical connection" because without it, the above two loops can not reach each. However, by using topological sorting, since all nodes are in at least one loop, it will give empty result.
Is my thinking correct?
